Estoy forwardeando una discusion que aparecio en la lista de CAs de la 
GDC que me parece interesante compartir con ustedes.

La dividire en partes. La primer parte es la pregunta original. Las 
siguientes son las respuestas.

Pido disculpas para los que no entiendan el idioma, pero no tengo tiempo 
como para traducirlo.

La informacion de contacto de los que escriben las elimine por razones 
eticas de la lista.



-------- Original Message --------

Hello everybody.

Well, I've decided that at this point in time I really want to try 
to get into the industry and put off gradschool for a little bit 
after graduating from university, so I'm starting my future job 
search.  This means working on the oh-so-wonderful resumes (I say 
resumes because I am working on a general as well as a few 
specialized resumes), and I have some questions pertaining to a game-
development related resume.

One of my main questions relates to the fact that in the realm of 
game development-related concepts, I'm mainly self-taught.  
Therefore, I can't list under my formal education skills game-
related stuff, like 2D/3D graphics, collision detection, simple game 
AI, level loading, game data management, etc.  However, can I put 
these under my skills?  And should I point out the fact that I'm 
self-taught?  I'm not sure if that's would be good or bad.  On the 
one hand, it shows I'm motivated enough to learn on my own, on the 
other, it shows that I didn't recieve a formal education on these 
things.

Another thing is, how important is a resume for an entry-level 
position being one page?  I've heard adages about resumes being an 
advertisement, not a book, and that HR people only want to scan 
them, not read them.  

if the one page rule is cardinal, what type of jobs should I put on 
a game-related resume?  Throughout my college career, I've worked 
many jobs, usually 2 or 3 at a time.  Each of them (aside from a few 
like dishwasher and gas attendant) have some sort of relevance to 
them.  For example, I was a nightshift manager at a gas station for 
a year.  This shows I have experience coordinating people.  However, 
I don't think that's important for an entry level job.  I was also a 
teaching assistant, which shows that I have a strong familiarity 
with operating systems.  Would this be a good thing to put on my 
resume?

Also, I have put a lot of my personal game projects on my website.  
Would it be helpful to point this out in my resume and provide a 
link to the games?  or would it make my resume look less 
professional?

I come to you guys with these questions because I know that you guys 
are knowledgeable and usually willing to help.  I also know that 
there may be a few others who have the same questions, but are 
afraid to ask, so any help that you give me might help them as well.

ok, thanks everyone, and I'm eager to see what your responses are!

Lukas
